titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the International Union of Steam Engineers Photographs PHOTOS.288
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Caroline Evans

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2015-11-20T10:13-0500

did.unittitle: International Union of Steam Engineers Photographs

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

physdesc.extent: in one flat box and one folder in shared housing

did.abstract: The National Union of Steam Engineers was founded in 1896 in an effort to address wages, benefits, work week hours, and working conditions. Local union charters were granted the following year, and the organization changed its name in 1898 to International Union of Steam Engineers to account for locals in Canada. The union adopted a steam gauge as its emblem, which continues to be the logo even after the organization has become the International Union of Operating Engineers as of 1928.This collection contains five contact prints and four glass negatives of New York delegates on their way to the 1908 convention of the International Union of Steam Engineers.

custodhist.head: Custodial History Note
custodhist.p: Materials purchased by David Yorke of Burnaby, British Columbia from CMYSales, a photo and ephemera shop in Bellrose, NY 11426. Materials purchased via E-Bay auction. Original provenance is unknown.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The National Union of Steam Engineers was founded in 1896 in an effort to address wages, benefits, work week hours, and working conditions for steam engineers and operators. Local union charters were granted the following year, and the organization changed its name in 1898 to International Union of Steam Engineers to account for locals in Canada. The union adopted a steam gauge as its emblem, which continues to be the logo even after the organization has become the International Union of Operating Engineers as of 1928.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of photographic contact prints and glass negatives of New York delegates on their way to the 1908 convention of the International Union of Steam Engineers (which later became known as International Union of Operating Engineers).

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Prints were rehoused into one acid-free folder, to be moved to a shared manuscript box. Four glass negatives were separated from the prints and are housed in one flat photo box.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; International Union of Steam Engineers Photographs; PHOTOS.288; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition Note
acqinfo.p: Donated by David Yorke, circa 2009-2015. The accession number associated with this donation is 2015.037.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Materials in this collection, which were created in 1908, are in the public domain. Users need not secure permission from the Tamiment Library to publish or reproduce materials in this collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection has not been arranged by an archivist. The materials are arranged in the order in which they were received from the donor.
